Welcome back to the Delphi podcast.
I'm John, a ventures associate here at Delphi Ventures.
Today we're digging into one of the most ambitious real-world applications of DePIN to date.
I'm joined by Harry Dewhirst, co-founder and CEO of 375ai, a company building a decentralized network of sensors to capture and monetize real-world physical data at scale.
Think traffic flows, vehicles, weather conditions, and a lot more.
All captured directly from billboards and storefronts, processed by AI at the edge, and powered by onchain token incentives.
Delphi Ventures is proud to be participating in 375's upcoming fundraising round and to be working together with Harry and the team on this to scale the network.
Harry, it's awesome to have you.
Let's get into it.
Pleasure to be here.
Thanks.
So before we dive into the story of 375, I'd like to kind of hear your background.
I know you have a very impressive run both in Web2 and Web3, especially when it comes to monetizing data.
And so why don't you share some of your insights and experiences that kind of led you to build 375?
Sure.
So I've been an entrepreneur most of my, well, my whole career really.
I started a company when I was in my 20s and that was a business that was helping mobile operators monetize their users information more specifically.
So we raised investment from some leading venture firms in the valley, Sequoia, Excel, as well as strategic investors like Vodafone and Telefonica, and we built a platform that enabled them to make sense and understand who their customers were, but then of course be able to target and profile them for paying customers such as brands and advertisers.
We ultimately sold that business to Singtel, the large mobile operating holding company in Singapore that have operations across Southeast Asia, Australia, India.
And I moved out to Singapore and then built this data business inside of Singtel for monetizing and profiling and targeting their consumer base or their subscriber base.
I then went on to be president at another data business called Bliss, which was using mobile phones as a way to understand people's movement in the real world.
So apps, by this time, you know, my first business was started before iPhone and Android even existed.
By this point in time, you know, apps were prevalent and phones had GPS and things like that.
So there were lots of more data points made available, and this Bliss was a platform that took in huge amounts of data about where devices went and could use that as a sample to understand the general movement of people in the real world, and that was very, very valuable to retailers, to quick-service restaurants, to luxury brands, hotels, and so on.
We ultimately sold that business to private equity and then it ultimately sold to T-Mobile in the US.
My last feray before starting 375ai was I was appointed CEO of Lynxys, the Wi-Fi router company that most people over 35 have had one in their home at some point.
And that was a different experience for me outside of my entrepreneurial roots, but approached it in the same vein nonetheless.
We were listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange, raised $160 million to take it private, and reinvent the business, and it was there that I stumbled across projects like Helium that just fascinated me.
And this is three, four years ago.
It's fascinated me and now my co-founder Rob so much that we left Lynxys to launch 375, and that's yeah, just coming up to almost three years ago to the day.
Very cool.
Were you always interested in crypto?
Like, you were the CEO of Lynxys and then you identified Helium.
So I was kind of curious.
Yeah, I had, I didn't have any professional exposure to crypto, but I was holding crypto probably since 2015, 16.
So, but as a retail investor.
And I did have friends that had moved into working in the crypto space as their career.
So I did, you know, tag along often and particularly as my interest in, in, you know, DY at the time, now kind of more broadly known as DePIN, grew, I, you know, I would go to all the conferences and so on and and had a fair number of friendly faces to see thanks to people who are friends who had moved into the industry.
But no, prior to 375, my interest in crypto was really as a, you know, a retail investor.
I rode some of the waves.
I distinctly remember being stuck in barley in a volcano with Bitcoin going to 20K, which was very exciting.
I don't know what year, what cycle that was, but I remember being very excited stuck on an island in the Southeast Asia.
Interesting.
Very cool.
So, so at one point 375, you know, you were deploying other people's DePIN devices and then you kind of made a hard pivot and decided to build your own network, own devices, own token.
What was the light bulb moment for you to make that switch?
Yeah, so you're absolutely right.
We started the business with an intention of being, you know, an enterprise or the biggest enterprise-grade deployer of other people's DePIN stuff, which we achieved, and we became one of the larger miners of various different projects in the space, Helium, Xnet, and a handful of others.
It was during that time that we learned obviously a lot about what we like about certain projects, what we don't.
Whether that's the tokenomics, whether that's kind of the concepts, whether it's the demand side, whether it's the business model.
So what we decided was that we were sitting on an exclusive contract that was very valuable then and remains very valuable to this day, which was a real estate relationship to give us access to 50,000 very sought-after unique locations on billboards with a publicly traded company called Outfront.
We decided that that asset was really underleveraged.
And whilst we were deploying other gear there and monetizing it, we thought that there was a bigger opportunity.
So we kind of went to the drawing board and said, "Okay, like if we were to build our own project, what pieces would we take from all of these experiences that we've had with all of these other projects, what kind of pitfalls would we look to try and avoid?"
And that's really where the kind of ideation for what is now 375 and the data intelligence network started.
Plus, of course, my background and experience in data, it was an obvious path to take, you know, using the latest and greatest technology to attack real-world data in a new and novel way.
Got it.
Okay.
So before we go deeper into mechanics, could you give us maybe a basic overview of 375 AI right now, like what, what, what actually you're tracking, what type of real-world data we're talking about, and what are the node types?
Yeah, sure.
So 375 is an edge data intelligence network.
We've deployed and developed advanced sensors that we've placed across strategic locations across the US.
These devices consist of an Nvidia GPU core which runs its own LLM, its own computer vision software, and is something that we train to our specification.
Into that is a multitude of sensors.
The primary, the primary and the most expensive or valuable sensors being six very specialized cameras.
And then a host of other kind of smaller sensors, microphones, atmospheric, environmental, and so on.
That data gets fed into the core and as much information as the model is trained to do so is extracted from it.
So our initial focus has been on vehicular data because of the placements being on some of the busiest highways in the country.
You know, think eight lanes of traffic going two directions at 80 mph, capturing everything from capturing and identifying everything from make, model, color, number of occupants in the car, license plates, incidents on the road, whether that's collisions, erratic driving, ambulances, tow trucks, and then when it comes to commercial vehicles, capturing every characteristic of that commercial vehicle, whether that's the US Department of Transport number, whether it's a trailer ID, from containers, what the carrier is.
So, is it a Hapag Lloyd trailer?
Is it an Evergreen trailer?
Is it a UPS truck, a FedEx truck, or any other independent email address or phone number that we're able to pull off of these moving vehicles as commercial vehicles are a particularly interesting category as we come on to, you know, why is this data valuable and what's it for?
Okay.
And you know, I mean, everybody talks about like real-world data being inherently useful and valuable, but it can also be quite noisy, right?
Like it can be messy, unstructured.
What makes the data that you're tracking actually useful for businesses and make them willing to pay for it?
Sure.
I mean, of course, there's no, it's no surprise to anyone that there's, you know, there's millions and millions of cameras out there in theory capturing this information, but it isn't data.
It's just video.
And what our system is doing is taking these six high-definition specialized streams of video and on the fly and at the edge in real time converting that into data in anonymized format in a very privacy-compliant and respectful way because the video itself never leaves the device.
So there is no privacy concern or regulation to be abided by because the video is neither stored nor used.
The AI scans it, extracts the information it needs, and then expunges it.
That's never to our knowledge been done at least at this scale before.
And as we roll out more and more cameras and more and more devices, and we'll come on to a smaller form factor device that we've been working on, but it, you know, it's normalizing that unstructured data into something that is usable, and and of course once it's into a usable format, you can combine it with other forms of data.
And then you're off to the races.
And really this is the first time deterministic data about what's going on on the corner of Broadway and Howard in New York has ever been possible.
And that's thanks to the advent and development in technology.
So, could you maybe give a concrete, like, some concrete examples of what type of data could be used for what type of application?
I mean, you know, one example that comes to mind is, you know, hedge funds and traders have been, you know, it's known that they've been tracking, you know, satellite and drone imagery, right, to gain an edge in all sorts of like clever ways, you know, they've been like maybe like monitor a parking lot to have a sense of like how a retailer shop is doing or, you know, if there's a natural disaster, they can check for damages in power plants and all sorts of like clever techniques, but I'm kind of curious like what businesses can get out of 375 that they can't through these like alternative means of capturing real-world data.
Yeah.
Some concrete examples would really help.
Sure.
So, let's use that example there of hedge funds and satellite imagery.
So the reason they're buying that data is to give them an edge on understanding whether Best Buy's results or Target's results or what Walmart's results are going to be up or down or left or right from forecast, and looking at parking lots and looking at the visitation of parking lots based on satellite imagery.
That's a pretty cool way to approach it.
Now the challenges are those images are only available when the satellite happens to be flying over that particular place.
The image is expensive.
They're very expensive to book and order those images.
They are a snapshot in time and also they don't have really any way to calculate any form of unique because of the vantage point at which they're being viewed is really just counting the total number, not not the unique number on one day versus another day.
The difference in fidelity between that and ours.
So let's use an example whereby our devices are deployed outside of on the thoroughfare to a Walmart or to a super center and our device is capturing every single vehicle down to a license plate, which is a unique identifier, which therefore can be used to understand both the reach and the frequency accurately because you know, and we've seen this in the data there, our, you know, our first device that we deployed and that was built by our chief AI officer in his garage in Redwood City, California.
He has had that device up and running on the on a billboard in on the 101 that we have a truck, a Ford Transit van that we have seen thousands and thousands and thousands and thousands of times.
I don't know what this person does, but they drive past back and forth hundreds of times a week.
And that of course in another means would be considered 100 people, but it's in fact not.
Now that's one extreme example, but by being able to have a very granular and high-fidelity view on the number, the frequency, and then also from the car itself, there is a lot of assumed demography and other attributes that can be understood, you know, is it all Kia Sportage or is it Range Rovers?
There's a very different demographic between those two vehicles.
